newsitem.title: INDONESIA: ASEAN customs urged to improve procedures.
newsitem.headline: ASEAN customs urged to improve procedures.

text.p: Indonesia's Finance Minister Mar'ie Muhammad urged Southeast Asian customs officials on Wednesday to improve their administrations to smooth the flow of trade.
Directors-general of customs of the seven-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) earlier opened a two-day meeting to review progress in improving the handling of cross-border goods.

"Ensuring that customs administration supports legitimate economic activities and ensures a smooth flow of goods across our national boundaries is crucial to our efforts to create a stronger ASEAN," Mar'ie said in an address delivered on his behalf.
He said customs officials continued to have a crucial role to play. They had to effectively and fairly apply existing tariffs and enforce legitimate rules against smuggling and illegal trade.
They also had to improve their work "to ensure that customs administration is not seen as a bottleneck to investment and production".
ASEAN Secretary-General Ajit Singh said progress had already been made in such areas as harmonising tariff nomenclature, valuation and procedures.
Other enhancements underway included measures such as the common customs form, the green lane system to speed clearance of goods and the drafting of an ASEAN agreement on customs.
Noting that ASEAN was the world's fourth largest trading entity with imports and exports of more than $500 billion in 1994, Singh added:

"Efficient customs administrations with simplified, transparent and predictable customs procedures would certainly reduce costs and enable the private sector to function more smoothly and effectively."
ASEAN comprises Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Vietnam, Brunei and the Philippines.
